bioghist.p: In 1929, Allen Rogers, Lucius Mayer, and Raymond Brooks formed the Mining Club for the purpose of holding monthly luncheons in New York for mining engineers. This club became a place for mining men to meet, socialize, and discuss business matters. Talks on a variety of mining-related subjects, such as the progress of mining, metallurgical and petroleum problems, and equipment, were given at the monthly luncheons.

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of the records of the Mining Club. Materials include correspondence, meeting minutes, financial statements, membership lists, and annual reports. Also included is a nearly complete run of the club's yearbook, which includes member lists, articles of incorporation and by-laws, lists of speakers and lecture titles (after the 1940s), a history of the club and the "house rules."

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
